Again and again he declares that he should never have left Rome, as he did, before he was assailed by name ; but should have appealed to force against Clodius, in which case, he says, aut occubui-seem honeste, aut victores hodie viveremus, Att. iii. 15, 4. His leaving Rome he calls turpissimum consilium, and, somewhat weakly, upbraids Atticus and his other friends for not dissuading him from such a step.
